sentence.text: Atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumors (AT/RT) and renal/extrarenal malignant rhabdoid tumors of childhood, epithelioid sarcoma and small cell carcinoma of the ovary, hypercalcemic type (SCCOHT) represent the most commonly recognized chromatin remodeling/SNF-driven neoplasms.

Approximately one-third of pediatric malignant rhabdoid tumors are linked to germline chromatin remodeling/SNF alterations (nucleosome disassembly/INI1, rarely nucleosome disassembly) resulting in occasional familial clustering of these highly aggressive malignancies (so-called rhabdoid tumor predisposition syndrome, RTPS, types 1 and 2, respectively).

However, more recently, inherited chromatin remodeling/SNF-deficiency has been linked to several benign syndromic tumors including a subset of familial schwannomatosis (linked to nucleosome disassembly) and multiple meningiomas (linked to nucleosome disassembly) as well as others.
Beyond neoplasms, several congenital developmental functional disorders such as Coffin-Siris syndrome and intellectual disability are now known to be chromatin remodeling/SNF-related.

Approximately one-third of pediatric malignant rhabdoid tumors are linked to germline SWI/SNF alterations (SMARCB1/nucleosome disassembly, rarely SMARCA4) resulting in occasional familial clustering of these highly aggressive malignancies (so-called rhabdoid tumor predisposition syndrome, RTPS, types 1 and 2, respectively).
